comments.author: Kathy
comments.content: Here's my big question, 5 minutes into making this dish! Can I use a real good cider vinegar, or will I be totally "cooked" without the $36 dollar special apple balsamic? That'll teach me to start the recipe before REALLY reading it.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hi Kathy - the difference is that the cider balsamic is quite thick and sweet. So what you might be able to is reduce the cider vinegar with some sugar until syrupy. If you happen to have apple butter, add some of that and strain the result, that might be kinda close.

Michael

comments.author: Kathy
comments.content: Michael -- Your response comes as I lick the last sauce off the plate. My inclinations were good! I added 2T of balsamic vinegar, 1/4 C of good quality cider vinegar, and a T of sugar. Cringed when considering 8 T of butter in the sauce alone so I cut back to six. I also substituted a great cognac for the Calvados (I'm upstairs and all these bottles are downstairs; I don't pay as close attention to the producers as others). But what a fantastic dish! Next time I'll be prepared and take it over the top. Thanks!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Kathy - awesome! Glad to hear you worked out a substitution and that it turned out well.

comments.author: Alana
comments.content:
I made this dish for my new year's eve dinner and it blew my guests' minds. i had never eaten farro and it was hard to find in montreal, but i finally tracked it down at an italian specialty store (along with some kind of apple balsamic something).  the caraway seeds were inspired for adding some depth of flavour.
couldn't find fresh chanterelles so i used dried ones and still delicious.
good one for practicing the plating too. THANKS!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I'm so glad it was winner for you! Thanks for letting me know.

comments.author: Martin
comments.content: I found a helpful blog post about faro, which clarifies that it comes in different varieties, to which Michael alludes as well - farro perlato or semi pearled vs whole grain farro. Details here: http://www.beyondsalmon.com/2011/04/tricky-business-of-buying-farro.html
